title: ag.algebraic geometry - Logarithmic Darboux theorem
body: Let $X$ be a smooth complex analytic manifold and $D$ be a normal crossing divisor. Suppose that there is a complex analytic logarithmic symplectic structure on $X$ . Is there a Darboux like theorem that says that the complex analytic log symplectic form on a neighbourhood of a point is $\sum_{i=1}^r \frac{dx_i}{x_i}\wedge dx_{i+r}+\sum_{j=1}^{2(n-r)-1} dx_{2r+j}\wedge dx_{2r+j+1}$ , where $\{x_i\}$ 's are some local complex coordinates of $X$ and the divisor is given by the vanishing locus of $x_1\cdots x_r$ ? If this is a known result an explanation or a reference of the proof will be very helpful. ag.algebraic-geometry dg.differential-geometry sg.symplectic-geometry moduli-spaces Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Aug 10, 2020 at 12:14 asked Aug 10, 2020 at 11:38 S.D. 494 3 3 silver badges 9 9 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 2 1 $\begingroup$ For b-symplectic manifolds (i.e. $r=1$), a Darboux theorem is established in arxiv.org/abs/1512.05303 $\endgroup$ Tobias Diez –  Tobias Diez 2020-08-10 17:50:28 +00:00 Commented Aug 10, 2020 at 17:50 $\begingroup$ @Tobias Diez thanks $\endgroup$ S.D. –  S.D. 2020-08-11 08:56:40 +00:00 Commented Aug 11, 2020 at 8:56 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
